lines.text: [first lines]

a Paris street cafe]
Des cartes postales, m'sieur? Des cartes postales, sir?
[Man seated with lady shoos the vendor away]

[approaching Gordon and Hector's table]
Postal cards, m'sier? *Dirty* postcards?

[turning away, disgusted]
Uh!
Charming.
[taking the cards]
Would you like to look at them, Hector?
Certainly not!
How much are they?
Twenty francs.
There you are.
Merci m'sieur. Merci.
[Gordon tears up the cards, bows to the vendor, and throws the pieces away]
Why... why on earth did you do that?
Who knows, it may save the soul of some American tourist.
[last lines]
Darling, are you quite sure this isn't heaven?
I'm quite sure it is.
What do you think, Hector?
Bless you, my children, but don't deceive yourselves. This not heaven. It's too infernally hot.
[last lines]
Darling, are you quite sure this isn't heaven?
I'm quite sure it is.
What do you think, Hector?
Bless you, my children, but don't deceive yourselves. This is not heaven. It's too infernally hot.

You're a queer duck, Gordon. You've a future before you if you'd only follow it up. Those last cases I sent you, you handled brilliantly. And suddenly-this sort of thing. Why don't you come back to London with us tomorrow? I can get you a dozen briefs!
I'm through with London. I may go out to the East again, Doctor says England's too damp for me.
Nonsense. Think of your work.
My dear Hector, I've no intention of spending the rest of my life in an ill-ventilated courtroom waiting for twelve total strangers to make up their minds.
Oh, you'll never succeed at anything with that kind of attitude.
I shall succeed in keeping out of courtrooms.
Are you coming with us tonight or aren't you?
No.
[pause]
Is it white tie or dinner jacket?
Dinner jacket.
Then I shall come. You see, my valet ran away with my evening dress.
Why not call the police; have the fellow arrested?
Wearing evening dress is punishment enough.
